Apple___Apple_scab.cause_detail: The fungus Venturia inaequalis thrives in cool, moist spring conditions, spreading spores through rain splash.
prevention: Prune trees to improve air circulation
Rake and destroy fallen leaves each autumn
Plant scab-resistant apple varieties

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Leaves
treatment_steps.detail: Pick off and destroy all visibly scabbed leaves and fruit to reduce spore load.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray captan or myclobutanil every 7–10 days during wet spring weather.

treatment_steps.title: Monitor Regularly
treatment_steps.detail: Check new growth weekly and reapply fungicide after heavy rain.

Apple___Black_rot.cause_detail: Botryosphaeria obtusa enters through wounds and dead wood, spreading to fruit and leaves in warm, humid conditions.
prevention: Prune out all dead and diseased wood
Remove mummified fruit from trees and ground
Avoid wounding the bark during farm work

treatment_steps.title: Prune Infected Wood
treatment_steps.detail: Cut out all cankers and dead branches, cutting 15cm below visible infection.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Mummified Fruit
treatment_steps.detail: Collect and destroy all shrivelled fruit hanging on the tree — they harbour spores.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray captan or thiophanate-methyl from pink bud stage through summer.

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.cause_detail: The fungus Gymnosporangium requires both apple and nearby cedar/juniper trees to complete its life cycle. Spores travel on spring winds.
prevention: Remove cedar and juniper trees within 1km if possible
Plant rust-resistant apple varieties
Prune orange galls from cedar trees in winter

treatment_steps.title: Apply Preventive Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray myclobutanil or mancozeb starting at pink bud stage, before orange spores appear.

treatment_steps.title: Repeat Applications
treatment_steps.detail: Continue spraying every 7–10 days through petal fall, especially after rain.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Galls from Cedar
treatment_steps.detail: Cut off any orange, jelly-like galls from nearby cedar trees each spring.

Apple___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your apple tree shows no signs of infection. Continue your current care routine.
prevention: Maintain balanced fertilization each season
Water at the base — avoid wetting leaves
Inspect trees monthly for early warning signs

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

treatment_steps.title: Routine Maintenance
treatment_steps.detail: Continue regular pruning, feeding, and watering to keep the plant strong.

Blueberry___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your blueberry plant is in good condition.
prevention: Maintain soil pH between 4.5 and 5.5
Apply mulch to retain moisture and suppress weeds
Prune old canes each year to encourage new growth

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

treatment_steps.title: Routine Maintenance
treatment_steps.detail: Ensure consistent moisture and acidic soil conditions.

Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.cause_detail: The fungus Podosphaera clandestina spreads through airborne spores, thriving when days are warm and nights are cool and humid.
prevention: Space plants well to improve airflow
Avoid excess nitrogen fertilizer
Plant powdery mildew-resistant cherry varieties

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Growth
treatment_steps.detail: Prune off shoots showing white powdery coating and dispose of them away from the farm.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Sulfur Spray
treatment_steps.detail: Spray sulfur or potassium bicarbonate solution every 7 days until symptoms disappear.

treatment_steps.title: Improve Air Circulation
treatment_steps.detail: Thin dense canopy areas so wind can pass through and dry leaf surfaces faster.

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your cherry tree is thriving.
prevention: Prune for open canopy and sunlight penetration
Water consistently at the base of the tree
Check for pest damage monthly

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.cause_detail: The fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis survives in crop residue and spreads rapidly during warm nights with high humidity and heavy dew.
prevention: Rotate crops — avoid continuous maize planting
Plant resistant hybrid varieties
Till soil after harvest to bury infected residue

treatment_steps.title: Scout Fields Early
treatment_steps.detail: Check lower leaves at knee-height stage. Act before lesions reach upper canopy.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray strobilurin or triazole fungicides at first sign of lesions, before tasselling.

treatment_steps.title: Manage Crop Residue
treatment_steps.detail: After harvest, plough under or burn infected stalks and leaves to break the disease cycle.

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.cause_detail: Puccinia sorghi spores travel long distances on wind. Infection is favoured by cool temperatures (16–23°C) and high humidity.
prevention: Plant early-maturing rust-resistant hybrids
Avoid late planting when spore pressure is high
Monitor fields weekly during cool, wet periods

treatment_steps.title: Assess Severity
treatment_steps.detail: Light rust on lower leaves rarely needs treatment. Act if pustules reach the ear leaves.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray propiconazole or azoxystrobin at early rust appearance, especially for sweet corn.

treatment_steps.title: Harvest Promptly
treatment_steps.detail: If infection is severe and crop is near maturity, harvest early to minimise losses.

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.cause_detail: Exserohilum turcicum infects through stomata during cool (18–27°C), wet periods. Long, grey-green cigar-shaped lesions are the key symptom.
prevention: Use resistant hybrids with Ht genes
Practise crop rotation with non-host crops
Manage crop residue by deep ploughing after harvest

treatment_steps.title: Identify Early
treatment_steps.detail: Look for elliptical greyish lesions on lower leaves. Early detection is critical.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray mancozeb or azoxystrobin at tasselling if disease pressure is high.

treatment_steps.title: Residue Management
treatment_steps.detail: Plough crop debris deep into the soil after harvest to reduce inoculum for next season.

Corn_(maize)___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your maize crop looks strong and healthy.
prevention: Maintain balanced NPK fertilization
Ensure adequate drainage in the field
Scout for pests and disease every 2 weeks

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Grape___Black_rot.cause_detail: Guignardia bidwellii overwinters in mummified berries and infected canes. Spores release during rainy spring periods, infecting young tissue.
prevention: Remove all mummified berries from vines and ground
Prune vines for open canopy and good airflow
Apply fungicide protectively from bud break

treatment_steps.title: Remove Mummies
treatment_steps.detail: Collect and destroy all dried, shrivelled berries — they are the primary source of infection.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide at Bud Break
treatment_steps.detail: Begin spraying myclobutanil or captan at early bud break. Repeat every 10 days until veraison.

treatment_steps.title: Post-Harvest Sanitation
treatment_steps.detail: After harvest, rake and dispose of all fallen leaves and fruit to reduce overwintering spores.

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).cause_detail: A complex of wood-rotting fungi (Phaeomoniella, Phaeoacremonium) colonise the vine's permanent wood over many years, blocking water flow.
prevention: Make clean pruning cuts and seal large wounds immediately
Prune during dry weather to reduce infection risk
Remove and burn severely infected vines promptly

treatment_steps.title: Prune Out Infected Wood
treatment_steps.detail: Cut back to healthy white wood, well below any brown streaking or discolouration.

treatment_steps.title: Protect Pruning Wounds
treatment_steps.detail: Apply wound sealant paste (containing Trichoderma) to all cuts larger than 1cm immediately after pruning.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Dying Vines
treatment_steps.detail: Vines showing apoplexy (sudden wilting) should be removed and burned to prevent spread.

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.cause_detail: The fungus Isariopsis clavispora thrives where leaves stay wet. Dense canopies and overhead irrigation are the main risk factors.
prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation — use drip systems
Maintain open canopy by leaf thinning
Apply fungicide protectively during wet periods

treatment_steps.title: Improve Canopy Airflow
treatment_steps.detail: Remove leaves around grape clusters to allow faster drying after rain or dew.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray mancozeb or copper-based fungicide at first signs of angular leaf spots.

treatment_steps.title: Switch to Drip Irrigation
treatment_steps.detail: Replace overhead sprinklers with drip lines to keep foliage dry.

Grape___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your grapevine is in excellent condition.
prevention: Train vines on trellis for maximum airflow
Monitor soil moisture — avoid waterlogging
Inspect for mealybugs and leafhoppers monthly

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).cause_detail: The bacteria Candidatus Liberibacter asiaticus is injected into the tree by the Asian citrus psyllid insect as it feeds. There is currently no cure.
prevention: Use only certified disease-free nursery trees
Control Asian citrus psyllid with insecticides
Remove and burn any infected trees immediately

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Trees
treatment_steps.detail: There is no cure. Remove and burn all infected trees immediately to protect neighbouring citrus.

treatment_steps.title: Control the Psyllid Vector
treatment_steps.detail: Spray imidacloprid or dimethoate on remaining healthy trees to kill psyllid insects before they spread the bacteria.

treatment_steps.title: Replant with Resistant Stock
treatment_steps.detail: Source certified greening-free seedlings from a licensed nursery for replanting.

Peach___Bacterial_spot.cause_detail: Xanthomonas arboricola bacteria spread explosively during warm, rainy and windy weather, entering leaves and fruit through stomata and wounds.
prevention: Plant resistant peach varieties
Install windbreaks to reduce wind-driven rain
Avoid overhead irrigation — use drip systems

treatment_steps.title: Apply Copper Spray
treatment_steps.detail: Spray copper hydroxide or copper oxychloride at petal fall and every 10 days during wet weather.

treatment_steps.title: Prune Infected Shoots
treatment_steps.detail: Remove and destroy twigs showing water-soaked lesions or cankers during dry weather.

treatment_steps.title: Avoid Nitrogen Excess
treatment_steps.detail: Reduce nitrogen fertilizer — lush, soft growth is far more susceptible to infection.

Peach___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your peach tree is in good health.
prevention: Prune annually for open vase shape and airflow
Fertilize appropriately — avoid excess nitrogen
Check for borers and aphids each spring

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.cause_detail: Xanthomonas campestris bacteria are splashed between plants by rain and spread on wind. Infection enters through leaf pores and tiny wounds.
prevention: Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants
Rotate crops — do not plant peppers in the same spot 2 years running
Switch to drip irrigation to keep foliage dry

treatment_steps.title: Apply Copper Bactericide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray copper hydroxide every 5–7 days during warm, wet weather from transplanting onwards.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Plants
treatment_steps.detail: Pull out and destroy plants that are heavily infected to prevent spread to healthy ones.

treatment_steps.title: Sanitise Tools
treatment_steps.detail: Dip knives and scissors in 10% bleach solution between plants to avoid spreading bacteria by contact.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your bell pepper plant is thriving.
prevention: Ensure full sun — at least 6 hours per day
Water consistently at the base, not on leaves
Stake plants to prevent stem damage from wind

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Potato___Early_blight.cause_detail: The fungus Alternaria solani survives in soil and infected debris. It thrives when temperatures are 24–29°C with high humidity and frequent rain.
prevention: Rotate crops — avoid potato in the same field 2 years in a row
Avoid overhead watering — use drip irrigation
Space plants adequately for good air circulation

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Lower Leaves
treatment_steps.detail: Pinch off leaves showing brown target-ring spots and dispose of them away from the field.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray copper-based fungicide or Neem oil every 7–10 days, especially after rain.

treatment_steps.title: Improve Drainage
treatment_steps.detail: Ensure the field drains well after rain — waterlogged roots increase overall disease vulnerability.

Potato___Late_blight.cause_detail: Phytophthora infestans (a water mould) spreads through the air in cool (10–20°C), wet conditions and can destroy an entire field within days.
prevention: Plant only certified disease-free seed potatoes
Use late-blight resistant varieties
Hill soil over tubers to prevent spore contact

treatment_steps.title: Destroy Infected Plants Immediately
treatment_steps.detail: Do not compost. Remove infected plants in sealed bags and burn or bury them far from the field.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide Preventively
treatment_steps.detail: Spray chlorothalonil or mancozeb before symptoms appear during wet, cool weather forecasts.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Tubers
treatment_steps.detail: At harvest, remove and discard all diseased tubers. Do not store or replant them.

Potato___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your potato crop is growing well.
prevention: Hill soil around plants as they grow
Ensure good drainage — avoid waterlogged fields
Monitor for Colorado beetle and aphids weekly

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Raspberry___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your raspberry canes are in good health.
prevention: Remove old fruited canes after harvest each year
Maintain soil pH between 5.5 and 6.5
Ensure good drainage — raspberries dislike wet roots

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Soybean___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your soybean crop is in excellent condition.
prevention: Practise crop rotation with cereal crops
Plant at the correct depth and spacing for the variety
Scout for soybean aphid and stink bugs every 2 weeks

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Squash___Powdery_mildew.cause_detail: The fungus Podosphaera xanthii thrives when days are warm and dry but nights are cool and humid. Unlike most fungi, it does NOT need wet leaves to infect.
prevention: Plant powdery mildew-resistant squash varieties
Space plants far apart for maximum airflow
Avoid excess nitrogen which creates lush, susceptible growth

treatment_steps.title: Apply Neem Oil or Baking Soda Spray
treatment_steps.detail: Mix 1 tablespoon Neem oil + 1 litre water + a drop of soap. Spray all leaf surfaces every 7 days.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Heavily Infected Leaves
treatment_steps.detail: Prune off leaves that are more than 50% covered in white powder and dispose of them.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Sulfur Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: For serious infections, use a wettable sulfur spray. Do not apply when temperature exceeds 32°C.

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.cause_detail: The fungus Diplocarpon earliana causes irregular purple-red spots that dry out and give the leaf a scorched appearance. It spreads via water splash.
prevention: Plant certified disease-free runners
Avoid overhead irrigation — use drip watering
Mulch beds to stop soil splashing onto leaves

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Leaves
treatment_steps.detail: Carefully remove and destroy all badly infected leaves to reduce the source of spores.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray captan or myclobutanil at 10-day intervals during periods of wet weather.

treatment_steps.title: Renovate Beds After Harvest
treatment_steps.detail: Mow and remove all old foliage after the fruiting season, then apply a fresh layer of mulch.

Strawberry___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your strawberry plants are in excellent health.
prevention: Mulch beds with straw to keep fruit clean and dry
Replace plants every 3 years to maintain productivity
Inspect for slugs and spider mites regularly

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.cause_detail: Xanthomonas campestris bacteria spread explosively in warm rainy weather. The bacteria enter through tiny wounds and leaf pores, causing dark water-soaked spots.
prevention: Use certified pathogen-free seeds and transplants
Rotate tomato crops every 2 years
Use drip irrigation to keep foliage dry

treatment_steps.title: Apply Copper Bactericide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray copper hydroxide or copper oxychloride every 5–7 days during warm, wet weather.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Heavily Infected Plants
treatment_steps.detail: Pull out and destroy plants that are more than 50% infected to reduce bacterial load in the field.

treatment_steps.title: Sanitise Tools Daily
treatment_steps.detail: Disinfect all tools with a 10% bleach solution to prevent spreading bacteria by touch.

Tomato___Early_blight.cause_detail: The fungus Alternaria solani thrives at 24–29°C with high humidity. Older and stressed plants are infected first, with characteristic brown target-ring spots.
prevention: Rotate crops every 2 years
Avoid overhead watering — water at the base
Prune lower leaves to improve airflow at the base

treatment_steps.title: Prune Affected Leaves
treatment_steps.detail: Remove leaves with brown spots from the bottom of the plant upwards. Dispose away from the field.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray Mancozeb (2g per litre of water) or chlorothalonil every 7 days after rain.

treatment_steps.title: Mulch the Soil
treatment_steps.detail: Apply a thick layer of straw mulch around plant bases to stop fungal spores splashing from soil onto lower leaves.

Tomato___Late_blight.cause_detail: Phytophthora infestans can destroy an entire tomato crop in days under cool (10–20°C) wet conditions. Dark greasy patches appear on leaves and fruit.
prevention: Plant resistant tomato varieties
Destroy any infected plants or potato cull piles nearby
Avoid overhead irrigation during cool, cloudy weather

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Plants Immediately
treatment_steps.detail: Do not compost. Bag infected plants and burn or bury them far from the field — every hour matters.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide Preventively
treatment_steps.detail: Spray chlorothalonil or mancozeb before symptoms appear when wet, cool weather is forecast.

treatment_steps.title: Inspect Daily During Risk Periods
treatment_steps.detail: Scout the entire field every morning during cool, rainy weather. Catch it early or you will lose the crop.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.cause_detail: The fungus Cladosporium fulvum thrives when relative humidity exceeds 85%, especially in greenhouses. Yellow patches appear on top of leaves, olive mould below.
prevention: Ventilate greenhouses to keep humidity below 85%
Space plants well to improve airflow between rows
Plant leaf mould-resistant tomato varieties

treatment_steps.title: Reduce Humidity
treatment_steps.detail: Increase ventilation and heating during the night to reduce moisture on leaf surfaces.

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Leaves
treatment_steps.detail: Remove and destroy all leaves showing yellow patches and olive mould on the undersides.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Copper Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray copper-based fungicide every 7 days until conditions improve and symptoms stop spreading.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.cause_detail: Septoria lycopersici produces tiny circular spots with white centres and dark borders. It spreads rapidly by rain splash from infected lower leaves and soil.
prevention: Rotate tomatoes with non-host crops every 2 years
Mulch the soil to prevent spore splash from soil
Remove lower leaves as the plant grows

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Lower Leaves
treatment_steps.detail: Start from the bottom — remove all spotted leaves immediately and dispose of them.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray chlorothalonil or copper-based fungicide every 7–10 days during wet weather.

treatment_steps.title: Avoid Wetting Foliage
treatment_steps.detail: Switch to drip or base watering to stop splashing spores between plants.

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.cause_detail: Two-spotted spider mites (Tetranychus urticae) are tiny arachnids — not insects. They thrive in hot, dry, dusty conditions and reproduce extremely fast.
prevention: Keep plants well-watered — stressed plants attract mites
Encourage beneficial insects like ladybugs and lacewings
Avoid dusty conditions around the crop

treatment_steps.title: Spray Leaves with Water
treatment_steps.detail: A strong jet of water on the underside of leaves dislodges and kills many mites immediately.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Neem Oil or Insecticidal Soap
treatment_steps.detail: Spray neem oil or insecticidal soap solution thoroughly on all leaf surfaces, especially undersides, every 5–7 days.

treatment_steps.title: Use Miticide for Severe Cases
treatment_steps.detail: If population is very high, apply a registered miticide. Rotate between products to prevent resistance.

Tomato___Target_Spot.cause_detail: The fungus Corynespora cassiicola causes distinctive concentric ring lesions resembling a target. It spreads via infected plant debris and water splash.
prevention: Rotate tomatoes with non-host crops
Maintain adequate plant spacing for air circulation
Avoid overhead irrigation

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Material
treatment_steps.detail: Pick off and destroy all leaves and fruit showing target-like ring spots.

treatment_steps.title: Apply Fungicide
treatment_steps.detail: Spray chlorothalonil or azoxystrobin every 7–14 days from first symptoms.

treatment_steps.title: Sanitise Field After Harvest
treatment_steps.detail: Till under or remove all crop debris to prevent the fungus from surviving into next season.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.cause_detail: This virus is injected into plants by the silverleaf whitefly (Bemisia tabaci) as it feeds. Infected plants show upward leaf curling and severe stunting — there is no cure.
prevention: Plant virus-resistant tomato varieties (TYLCV-R)
Use reflective silver mulch to repel whiteflies
Install yellow sticky traps to monitor and catch whiteflies early

treatment_steps.title: Remove Infected Plants
treatment_steps.detail: There is no cure. Remove and bag infected plants immediately to stop whiteflies feeding on them and spreading the virus.

treatment_steps.title: Control Whiteflies
treatment_steps.detail: Spray imidacloprid or spinosad on healthy remaining plants to kill whitefly populations before they spread further.

treatment_steps.title: Replant with Resistant Varieties
treatment_steps.detail: Source certified TYLCV-resistant tomato varieties for the next planting season.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.cause_detail: Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) spreads through direct contact — on hands, tools, clothing, and even cigarette tobacco. It survives for years in soil and debris.
prevention: Use certified virus-free seeds or resistant varieties
Wash hands thoroughly before entering the field
Sanitise all tools between plants with 10% bleach or milk solution

treatment_steps.title: Remove and Destroy Infected Plants
treatment_steps.detail: There is no cure. Remove infected plants immediately, bag them and burn or bury away from the field.

treatment_steps.title: Sanitise All Tools and Hands
treatment_steps.detail: Dip tools in a 10% bleach solution or rub with milk between plants. Wash hands with soap before re-entering the field.

treatment_steps.title: Do Not Smoke Near Plants
treatment_steps.detail: Tobacco products can carry mosaic virus. Do not smoke near the crop or touch plants after handling tobacco.

Tomato___healthy.cause_detail: No disease detected. Your tomato plant is in excellent health and growing well.
prevention: Water consistently at the base — never on leaves
Stake or cage plants before they need support
Inspect for early blight and hornworms weekly

treatment_steps.title: No Treatment Needed
treatment_steps.detail: Your crop appears healthy. Keep monitoring weekly for any changes.
